action.content:
Provide one single-word clue that relates to some of your team's words from the list below. You can choose to how many and to which words your clue relates to.
The goal is to have your partner guess all of your team's words based on the clues you give them, before the other team has uncovered all of theirs. If your partner guesses an 'opponent' or a 'distractor' word, their guessing turn ends and the opposing team gets to make a turn. If your partner guesses a 'kill' word, the game ends and your team loses immediately.
The more words your clue relates to, the quicker you can win the game, but the harder the associations may be to guess for your partner, so choose your clue word wisely. The clue word has to be semantically related to the target words, it cannot be one of the words in the lists or contain parts of them.

Always give your single-word clue and your comma-separated list of related target words in the following format and make your answers as short as possible, never include any other text than is required in this form:

CLUE: <WORD>
TARGETS: <TARGETS>

Your team words are: elliptic, bashfulness, darer, dwarfism, dabbler, candleholder, cancelation, balsawood, banquette.
Your opponent's team words are: emotionality, nextdoor, photoelectron, backwardness, demobilization, serialization, undernourishment, nearsightedness.
Distractor words are: ungodliness, astrobiology, gyration, duckweed, dangerousness, fossilization, shuffler.
The kill words are: caretaking.
action.label: context

action.content:
<reasoning>
Let's tackle this clue-giving problem. The user's team has nine words: elliptic, bashfulness, darer, dwarfism, dabbler, candleholder, cancelation, balsawood, banquette. I need to come up with a single-word clue that relates to as many of these as possible. The clue can't be any of the words in the lists or contain parts of them.

First, I'll look for common themes or relationships among the team's words. Let's list them again:

elliptic – maybe related to geometry or shapes?
bashfulness – an emotion, specifically shyness.
darer – someone who dares, a daredevil.
dwarfism – a condition of being small.
dabbler – someone who tries things without much commitment.
candleholder – an object that holds a candle.
cancelation – the act of canceling.
balsawood – a type of wood.
banquette – a long upholstered seat, maybe furniture.

Looking for connections. Let's see:

Elliptic could relate to circles or geometry. Bashfulness is an emotion. Darer is about daring. Dwarfism is physical. Dabbler is about trying. Candleholder is an object. Cancelation is an action. Balsawood is a material. Banquette is furniture.

Hmm. Maybe some words relate to parts of the body? Dwarfism is a condition, but not a body part.
action.label: response

content.message: Your answer contained more than two lines, please only give one clue and your targets on two separate lines.
